newsitem.title: UK: Strong sterling pounds UK grain markets.
newsitem.headline: Strong sterling pounds UK grain markets.

text.p: A strong sterling hammered the UK physical grain and futures markets on Friday.
"There is some dissatisfaction with Thursday's tender result but sterling has been the dominant factor during the day," said a trader.
On Friday the pound touched $1.5930, its highest level since early October last year.
Traders said a possible revaluation of the green pound was also on the cards which would hit intervention prices.
Wheat futures closed one to 1.50 stg down after being as much as 1.80 stg below Thursday's close at one stage. Turnover was 1,214 lots.
Barley finished 1.75 to one stg down after trading 72 lots.
In Amsterdam the milling wheat futures market closed unchanged.
Active trading was reported on the UK delivered market with a higher tonnage changing hands.
"There is blood running in the gutters," said a one trader.
Feed wheat was trading as low as 99 stg in some areas for November while in East Anglia it fetched 100 stg.
Lowest reported price was 97 stg paid for feed wheat in the Shropshire/Cheshire area for spot.
"People are saying the farmers are not selling, but the co-ops do seem to be involved," said one trader.
Traders on the fob sector said the market appeared to be stuck.

"Fob sellers haven't been following the the futures and are refusing to move from Thursday's levels. But I don't read anything significant into this. Only that they may feel they had enough for this week and want to start afresh next week," said a trader.
"Prices have not really moved during the day, but if futures stay down the fob market will creak on Monday," said another.
